You will still see ads, but they may not be based on your interests.

"Activity recognition allows apps and services to receive regular updates from Google on your current activity. For example, Google can determine if you’re walking, driving, cycling or stationary.
If high accuracy is turned off, device sensors such as the accelerometer will be used to detect activity.
Sensor and audio data are never recorded or shared with Google or apps."

resources.string:
• Google can help you fill in forms based on what’s on your screen.
  • You can see and manage your auto-fill info in Settings.
  • Passwords are saved to Google Smart Lock for Chrome and Android.
With a single tap, fill in passwords, addresses, credit cards and other info saved to your Google Account.
Back up app data, Wi‑Fi passwords and other settings to Google Drive

"Automatically back up device data (such as Wi-Fi passwords and call history) and app data (such as settings and files stored by apps) remotely.
When you turn on automatic backup, device and app data is regularly saved remotely. App data can be any data that an app has saved (based on developer settings), including potentially sensitive data such as contacts, messages and photos."
Stop backing up your Wi‑Fi passwords, bookmarks, other settings and app data, plus delete all copies on Google Drive?
Please check your Internet connection and try again
Automatic backup ensures that you can easily restore or switch phones at any time. Find out more

"When you turn on automatic backup:
● Device settings and app data are periodically saved to a private folder in Google Drive. App data can be any data that an app has saved (based on developer settings), including potentially sensitive data such as contacts, messages and photos.
Large files, or files developers have chosen to exclude from the service, will not be backed up."
Photos and videos on this device sync to your Google Photos library so that you can search, edit, delete and share from any of your devices.

Tap to download Android Auto and stay connected on the road with the help of your personalised Google Assistant
Stay connected on the road with the help of your personalised Google Assistant
Behaviour

Your device uses motion and Bluetooth to work out when you’re in a moving vehicle.

Driving mode can then turn on automatically, and open Android Auto to help you stay connected while driving.

The next time you start driving, %1$s.

You can change this behaviour in driving mode settings.
Google Text-to-Speech

"To use Android Auto, you need these apps on your phone: Android Auto, Google Maps, Google Play Music and Google App.
Try downloading them again."

"This phone can't connect to your car screen, but it can still run Android Auto. Download the Android Auto app to get started.
%1$s"

"This phone can't connect to your car screen, but it can still run Android Auto. Unplug your phone and re-open the Android Auto app.
%1$s"

"Android Auto couldn't finish setting up.
Make sure that you have the most recent versions of Android Auto, Google Maps, Google Play Music and Google App installed on your phone, and try again."
The phone and the car are running incompatible software. For details, visit android.com/auto
Android Auto will turn on Bluetooth, pair and sync your contacts with your car.
Turn on Bluetooth, pair and sync your contacts with your car.

Allow your car to access and display notifications from your phone.
%1$s
Android Auto will resume when your car is parked. Already parked? Put on the handbrake.

"Many features of Android Auto require a wireless data connection. You are responsible for data charges.
When connected to the in-dash display of a compatible vehicle, Android Auto may send navigation and media information to that vehicle for purposes such as displaying that information in other vehicle systems, i.e. instrument clusters and heads-up displays. Please consult your vehicle's documentation to learn more about your vehicle manufacturer's handling of information received from products like Android Auto.
If Android Auto is connected to your in-dash display in a compatible vehicle, your vehicle may also send data from its sensors to your device as follows:
Vehicle GPS data may be used by your device in the same way the device uses its own GPS data; and will be available to apps on your device according to your device and Google Account settings and app permissions. To learn more about a particular app developer’s handling of data, please consult that app’s documentation.
Certain vehicle information (for example, headlights, hand brake, compass and gear) will be available to Android Auto-compatible apps to help customise the app experience, such as displaying different graphics for day and night, or setting screen interaction limits based on when you're driving. To learn more about a particular app developer’s handling of data, please consult that app’s documentation.
Google may access other data about your vehicle, such as the make, model, fuel level, wheel speed, odometer and gear, and whether the passenger seat is occupied. This data is not linked to your Google Account and will be used in accordance with the Google Privacy Policy."
"Make sure that the car's date and time are set correctly."
"Make sure that the car's date and time are set correctly, and that %1$s has been updated."

"Check your USB connection, and make sure that you're using a high-quality cable.

"To help improve your search experience, Google can store and use links, provided by apps, to content that you've visited in apps."

"When you pause Location History, places that you go with your devices will stop being added to your Location History map. This limits functionality of some Google products over time, such as Google Maps and Google Now.
Remember, pausing this setting doesn’t delete any previous activity, but you can view and manage this information in your "Location History map.
This may change the Location mode that you’ve selected for your device. For details, go to %s.
Use Google’s Location service; as part of this service, anonymous location data will be sent to Google when your device is on.
Use GPS, Wi‑Fi, mobile networks and sensors
Use Wi‑Fi, mobile networks and sensors
Turn on Wi-Fi

Your device will create and store a list of places that you visit frequently. You can view and delete this information or turn off this feature. This information will not be accessed or used by any Google service without your consent. Learn more

"Google’s Location service improves location accuracy by using Wi‑Fi and mobile networks to help estimate your location. Anonymous location data will be sent to Google when your device is on.
Turning this off will result in your device only using GPS for location. This may impact the accuracy of location used by apps such as Maps and Find My Device."

"Google’s location service improves location accuracy by using Wi‑Fi, mobile networks and sensors to help estimate your location. Google may collect location data periodically and use this data in an anonymous way to improve location accuracy and location-based services.
Turning this off will result in your device only using GPS for location. This may impact the accuracy of location used by apps such as Maps and Find My Device."

Location History helps you get useful information such as automatic commute predictions, improved search results and more useful ads on and off Google. It does this by creating a private map of where you go with your signed-in devices.

To create this map, Google regularly obtains location data from devices for which you’ve turned on Location History. This data is collected even when you aren’t using a specific Google product.

Remember, location data may be saved from any signed-in devices for which you’ve turned on Location History. You can always control and review your activity at myaccount.google.com.
Google Location Settings
Add names, email addresses or phone numbers
"Sorry, we're having a problem processing your request at the moment. Please try again later."
By turning on Location Sharing, you agree to the Korean Location ToS

Location History is required for Location Sharing and also helps you get useful information, such as automatic commute predictions, improved search results and more useful ads on and off Google. To do so, Location History creates a private map of where you go with your signed-in devices.

To create this map, Google will regularly obtain location data from devices where you have enabled Location History, including when you aren’t using a specific Google product.

You can pause Location History whenever you like, but this doesn’t delete any previous activity. Find out more.
Add your name to your Google account so that people know who’s sharing. Your name may also appear in other Google products, such as when you send an email.
Missing name
You must have a data connection to see location-sharing settings. Please check your connection or try again later.

"Location Sharing lets you share your real-time location from your devices (using Location History) with people that you choose.

People that you share your location with can see your name, photo and real-time location across Google products, including Google+ and Google Hangouts. Your shared location may include information about where you are, where you've just been, what you're doing (such as driving or walking), your device (such as battery life or GPS connections) and your places (such as home, work and destinations). Find out more"

By continuing, you agree that this device may also automatically download and install updates and apps from Google, your operator and your device’s manufacturer, possibly using mobile data. Some of these apps may offer in-app purchases.
To remove apps, go to Settings > Apps or Application manager. Then tap the app that you want to uninstall (you may need to swipe right or left to find the app). Then tap Uninstall or Disable.
You also hereby consent and grant preloaded Google apps permission to access information and functions on your device. See this page for more information on usage of these permissions.

Backup data will not count towards your Drive storage quota."
Easily restore your data or switch phones at any time. Your backup includes apps, app data, call history, contacts, device settings (including Wi‑Fi passwords and permissions) and SMS.

"Easily restore your data or switch phones at any time. Your backup includes apps, app data, call history, contacts, device settings (including Wi‑Fi passwords and permissions) and SMS.
Your backups are uploaded to Google and encrypted using your Google Account password. For some data, your device’s screen lock PIN, pattern or password is also used for encryption."

Easily restore your data or switch phones at any time. Your backup includes apps, app data, call history, contacts, device settings (including Wi‑Fi passwords and permissions), photos, videos and SMS. Photos and videos sync to your Google Photos library and may be used across services.

"Easily restore your data or switch phones at any time. Your backup includes apps, app data, call history, contacts, device settings (including Wi‑Fi passwords and permissions), photos, videos and SMS. Photos and videos sync to your Google Photos library and may be used across services.
Your backups are uploaded to Google and encrypted using your Google Account password. For some data, your device’s screen lock PIN, pattern or password is also used for encryption."
Data will be used according to Google’s Privacy Policy.
Data will be used according to Google’s Privacy Policy (including collection, storage and usage of personal information) and the Location Terms of Service.
Tap to find out more about each service, such as how to turn it on or off later. ^1

"App details including in-app purchases can be found in the Play Store. App data & settings sync to devices signed in with your Google Account.
Use of instant apps is governed by the "Google Play Terms of Service". "Learn more.

Use Google’s Location service to help apps determine your location. Google may collect location data periodically and use this data in an anonymous way to improve location accuracy and location-based services.

"Google’s Location service uses sources such as Wi‑Fi, mobile networks and sensors to help estimate your device’s location. This service is active when your device’s Location setting is on, and in a mode that uses Wi‑Fi or mobile networks to estimate location, such as either the High accuracy or Battery saving mode.
You can turn off this service by either:
"
Turning off the main Location setting on your device."
"
Leaving the main Location setting on and selecting a mode that uses GPS only, sometimes called Device only.

"Google’s Location Service uses sources such as Wi‑Fi, mobile networks and sensors to help estimate your device’s location.
You can turn off location by turning off the main location setting on your device. You can also turn off the use of Wi‑Fi, mobile networks and sensors for location in location settings."
"Tap 'Accept' to confirm your selection of these Google services settings."

"By tapping 'Accept', you agree to the "Google Terms of Service. You also confirm your selection of these Google services settings. Note: The Google Privacy Policy describes how data is handled when using Google services.
"By tapping 'Accept', you confirm your selection of these Google services settings. Note: The "Google Privacy Policy describes how data is handled when using Google services.

Help improve your Android experience by automatically sending diagnostic, device and app usage data to Google. This will help battery life, system and app stability and other improvements. Some aggregate data will also help Google apps and partners, such as Android developers. If your additional Web & App Activity setting is turned on, this data may be saved to your Google Account.

"This is general information about your device and how you use it (such as battery level, system and app activity and errors). The data will be used to improve Android, and some aggregated information will also help Google apps and partners, such as Android developers, make their apps and products better.
Turning off this feature doesn’t affect your device’s ability to send the information needed for essential services such as system updates and security."
If your additional Web & App Activity setting is turned on, this data may be saved to your Google Account. You can see your data, delete it and change your account settings at account.google.co
Allow Google Live wallpapers to respond to your location by accessing Google’s Location Service.

You can turn access to Google’s Location Service for live wallpapers on or off by going to Settings > Apps & notifications > App info. In the overflow menu, tap Show system > Live data wallpapers or Live Earth Wallpapers > Permissions.

By continuing, you agree that this device may also automatically download and install updates and apps from Google, your operator and this device’s manufacturer, possibly using mobile data. Some of these apps may offer in-app purchases.

"^1
Backup data will not count towards your child’s Drive storage quota."

"^1
Photos and videos on this device sync to your child’s Google Photos library so that your child can search, edit, delete and share from any of their devices. By default, full-resolution photos and videos are uploaded to Google Photos.
Backup data will not count towards your child’s Drive storage quota."
Easily restore data or switch phones at any time. This backup includes apps, app data, call history, contacts, device settings (including Wi‑Fi passwords and permissions) and SMS.

Backups are uploaded to Google and encrypted using your child’s Google Account password. For some data, the device’s screen lock PIN, pattern or password is also used for encryption."

"Easily restore data or switch phones at any time. This backup includes apps, app data, call history, contacts, device settings (including Wi‑Fi passwords and permissions), photos, videos and SMS. Photos and videos sync to your child’s Google Photos library and may be used across services.
Backups are uploaded to Google and encrypted using your child’s Google Account password. For some data, the device’s screen lock PIN, pattern or password is also used for encryption."

Use Google’s Location service to help apps determine this device’s location. Google may collect location data periodically and use this data in an anonymous way to improve location accuracy and location-based services.

"Google’s Location service uses sources like Wi‑Fi, mobile networks and sensors to help estimate this device’s location. This service is active when this device’s Location setting is on, and in a mode that uses Wi‑Fi or mobile networks to estimate location, such as either the High accuracy or Battery saving mode.
You can turn off this service by either:
"
Turning off the main Location setting on this device."
"
Leaving the main Location setting on and selecting a mode that uses GPS only, sometimes called Device only.

"Google’s Location Service uses sources such as Wi‑Fi, mobile networks and sensors to help estimate this device’s location.
You can turn off location by turning off the main location setting on this device. You can also turn off the use of Wi‑Fi, mobile networks and sensors for location in location settings."

Help improve the Android experience by automatically sending diagnostic, device and app usage data to Google. This won’t be used to identify your child and will help battery life, system and app stability and other improvements. Some aggregate data will also help Google apps and partners, such as Android developers. If additional Web & App Activity is turned on for your child, this data may be saved to their Google Account.

"This is general information about this device and how it’s used (such as battery level, system and app activity and errors). The data will be used to improve Android, and some aggregated information will also help Google apps and partners, such as Android developers, make their apps and products better.
Turning off this feature doesn’t affect this device’s ability to send the information needed for essential services such as system updates and security."
